1: 1 is the number of moons orbiting Earth.
2: 2 is the number of stars in a binary star system (a stellar system consisting of two stars orbiting around their center of mass).
3: 3 is the number of points received for a successful field goal in both American football and Canadian football.
4: 4 is the maximal number of horses in one row for carriage.
5: 5 is the number of permanent members with veto power on the United Nations Security Council.
6: 6 is the number of days taken to create the world by Yahweh in the Old Testament Book of Genesis, and the number of the day on which humankind were created.
7: 7 is the number of estimated objects that can be simultaneously held in human working memory.
8: 8 is the number of principles of Yong in Chinese calligraphy.
9: 9 is the number of innings in a regulation, non-tied game of baseball.
10: 10 is the number of Provinces in Canada.
11: 11 is the number of denominations of Canadian currency produced in large quantities.
12: 12 is the number of function keys on most PC keyboards (F1 through F12).
13: 13 is the number of Oscar nominations of actress Meryl Streep, who holds the record for the most Oscar nominated actress.
14: 14 is the number of points in a proposed republican constitution of the United Kingdom.
15: 15 is the number of balls in the eight ball variant of billiards.
16: 16 is the minimum age that one can drop out of school in most states of the US (however, restrictions apply and vary depending on state).
17: 17 is the maximum number of strokes of a Chinese radical.
18: 18 is the number of wheels on the most common type of North American tractor-trailer truck, which are hence often called 18-wheelers.
19: 19 is the final year a person is a teenager.
20: 20 is the number of baby teeth in the deciduous dentition.
21: 21 is the number of points required to win a game in badminton and table tennis (before 2001).
22: 22 is the number of players on the field in a football (soccer) match.
23: 23 is the number of minutes that all flashbacks take place before the assassination attempt on the president in the film Vantage Point.
24: 24 is the number of frames per second at which motion picture film is usually projected.
25: 25 is the number of points needed to win a set in volleyball under rally scoring rules.
26: 26 is the number of bones in the normal human foot and ankle.
27: 27 is the number of bones in the human hand.
28: 28 is the number worn by the Clemson Tigers' record breaking running back C.J.
29: 29 is the number of days it takes Saturn to orbit the Sun.
30: 30 is the consumption in pounds of candy annually per person in Denmark, the country with the highest candy consumption.
31: 31 is the number of days in the months January, March, May, July, August, October and December.
32: 32 is the number of rays in the Japanese Rising Sun on the cover of Incubus' 2006 album Light Grenades.
33: 33 is the temperature at which water boils according to the Newton scale.
34: 34 is the lucky number of Victor Pelevin's protagonist Stepan Mikhailov in the novel Numbers.
35: 35 is the basic film gauge in mm most commonly used for both analog photography and motion pictures.
36: 36 is the number of vehicles that run in each race of NASCAR's Camping World Truck Series.
37: 37 is the number of slots in European Roulette (numbered 0 through 36, the 00 is not used in European roulette as it is in American roulette).
38: 38 is the number of surviving plays written by William Shakespeare.
39: 39 is the duration, in nanoseconds, of the nuclear reaction in the largest nuclear explosion ever performed (Tsar bomb).
40: 40 is the number of years of marriage as the ruby wedding anniversary.
41: 41 is the age at which writer/director Tom Graeff (of Teenagers from Outer Space fame) committed suicide.
42: 42 is the number of museums in Amsterdam (Netherlands has the highest concentration of museums in the world).
43: 43 is the maximum number of cars participating in a NASCAR race in the Cup Series or Nationwide Series.
44: 44 is the number of candles in a box of Hanukkah candles.
45: 45 is the sapphire wedding anniversary in years of marriage.
46: 46 is the number of slices of pizza an average American kid eats in a year.
47: 47 is the number of El-Aurians Scotty manages to beam up before their ship is destroyed by the energy ribbon.
48: 48 is the number of Ptolemaic constellations.
49: 49 is the number of days and night Siddhartha Gautama spent meditating as a holy man.
50: 50 is the traditional number of years in a jubilee period.
